titleStmt.title: Adaptive Fuzzy Practical Fixed-Time Tracking Control of Nonlinear Systems

analytic.title: Adaptive Fuzzy Practical Fixed-Time Tracking Control of Nonlinear Systems

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The paper investigates an adaptive practical fixedtime control strategy for the output tracking control of a class of strict feedback nonlinear systems. By utilizing backstepping algorithm, finite-time Lyapunov stable theory and fuzzy logic control, a novel adaptive practical fixed-time controller is constructed. Fuzzy logic systems are introduced to approximate the unknown items of the system. Theoretical analysis proves that under the presented control strategy, the closed-loop system is practically fixed-time stable, and the tracking error converges to a small neighborhood of the origin within fixed-time interval, in which the convergence time has no connection with the initial states of the system. In the meantime, all the signals of the closed-loop system are bounded. At last, a numerical example is presented to indicate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed method.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: In many practical engineering applications, such as the aircraft's attitude tracking systems and bioreactor systems etc, system states and tracking errors are required to converge to zero or their small neighborhood in finite time. Compared with the traditional Lyapunov stability control, finite-time control (FTC) has better control performance, which is reflected not only in the transient performance, but also in the robustness effect of the closed-loop system. In 1965, the definition of FTC was first put forward. Especially for the past decades, the FTC problem of nonlinear systems has been widely concerned, and a number of related results have been achieved. [1], [2] and [3] focused on the finite time stability for continuous but non-Lipschitzian autonomous systems, discrete-time linear systems and a class of nonlinear systems in p normal form, respectively. Finite-time attitude tracking control was investigated in [4]- [8]. However, among the results obtained in the literature, the settling time is always related to the initial states. Once the initial states keep away from the equilibrium point, the convergence time will become longer. At present, fixed-time control provides a very efficient method to solve a fast convergence problem independent of the initial states.

More recently, many advanced works present the idea of fixed-time control algorithm by utilizing time-dependent state transformation to accomplish fixed-time convergence, which means that the convergence time can be predicted. So, it is significant that the convergence time can be measured without knowledge of the initial conditions. In 2012, the fixed time convergence problem and its stability were first proposed in [9]. [10] presented two kinds of fixed-time nonlinear control strategies for linear systems, by which predicted convergence time has nothing to do with the initial conditions and is able to be adjusted arbitrarily. The non-singular fixed-time algorithms were proposed for a class of second-order nonlinear systems, and for multi-agent systems in the shape of networks, respectively, see [11] and [12]. At present, among the results available for the fixed-time control, one of the most notable achievements is that the practical fixed-time stability was concluded from the inequalities in the form of V (x) ≤ -( µ 1 V (x) α + µ 2 V (x) β ) γ +ϱ with µ 1 , µ 2 , α, β, γ ∈ R, αγ < 1 and βγ > 1, see [10], [14] and [15]. Enlightened by the above-mentioned results and the fixed-time control on account of the Lyapunov stability theory (see [13]), we will discuss the feasibility of the adaptive fuzzy practical fixed-time stability based on backstepping strategy.

As we know, backstepping algorithm is a systematic synthesis method for uncertain systems, and is also a iterative design technique, in which the selection of Lyapunov functions are combined with the controller design. Currently, adaptive backstepping has been one of the important issues of theory and applications of adaptive control, and especially shows great potential to improve the quality of the transition process while dealing with many industrial control systems, such as hydraulic control, motor control and robot control etc, see [16]- [18] and [19]. In addition, when some unknown terms or parameters appear in the system, an adaptive controller is devised by introducing fuzzy logic or neural network systems, which provide the estimates of the unknown terms or parameters, see [20]- [29]. Specially, in [30], [31], adaptive fuzzy finite-time controllers are presented. However, to the best of our knowledge, there is little academic research about how to combine the fixed-time control with fuzzy logic systems by using backstepping scheme.

Inspired by the above research results, this paper will investigate the problem of adaptive fuzzy practical fixedtime tracking control for a class of strict feedback nonlinear systems by using backstepping algorithm. In the presence of the unknown terms of the system, the fuzzy logic systems are 2 utilized to approximate them. Theoretical study indicates that under the presented control strategy, the closed-loop system is practically fixed-time stable, the tracking error is able to converge to a small neighborhood of zero within a fixed-time interval, and the convergence time has no connection with the initial states. In the meantime, all the signals of the closedloop system are bounded. Briefly, the major contribution of our study can be briefly stated as follows:

(1) This paper attempts to combine the fixed-time control with the fuzzy logic control by using backstepping algorithm. Specifically, the fuzzy logic systems are introduced to approximate the unknown items.

(2) An adaptive practical fixed-time tracking controller is designed, and theoretical analysis illustrates that the closedloop system is practically fixed-time stable, the output signal is able to track the desired output signal at fixed time, and the convergence time has no connection with the initial states of the systems. Synchronously, all the signals of the system are also bounded at fixed time.

The structure of the paper is arranged as follows: Section II introduces the problem description and preliminaries. In the next section, an adaptive fuzzy practical fixed-time tracking controller is presented for a class of strict feedback nonlinear systems. In Section IV, the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed method is verified through a numerical example. At last, the research is concluded.

div.head: A. Problem formulation
div.p: Consider a class of strict feedback nonlinear systems described by
div.formula:        ẋi (t) = f i (x i (t)) + ψ i (x i (t))x i+1 (t), 1 ≤ i ≤ n -1, ẋn (t) = f n (x n (t)) + ψ n (x n (t)u(t), y(t) = x 1 (t),(1)
div.p: where Define the desired output signal as y d (t), which is continuous and differentiable up to the nth order. The main control objective is to devise an adaptive fuzzy practical fixed-time control strategy, such that i). The output tracking error of the closed-loop system is able to converge to a small neighborhood of zero in predefined fixed time, and the convergence time has nothing to do with the initial conditions.
ii) All the signals in the closed-loop system are bounded.

div.head: B. Some important definitions, lemmas and assumptions
div.p: In order to facilitate the control design and implementation, some important definitions, lemmas and assumptions are introduced.
Definition 1 [10] Consider a dynamical system in the following form

where x ∈ ℜ n denotes the state vector and f (•) is continuous function. Assume that the origin of the system (2) is stable based on Lyapunov function. If there exists finite convergence time T s (x 0 ) for all time t ≥ t s , satisfying x(t) = 0, thus the system (2) is finite-time stable. Definition 2 [10] Assume the system (2) is finite-time stable. The system (2) is fixed-time stable if there exists certain upper bound in convergence time, which has no connection with the state variables.
Lemma 1 [10] [14] [32] Let V (x) be a smooth function with V (x) ≥ 0. If the following inequality holds
div.formula: V (x) ≤ - ( µ 1 V (x) α + µ 2 V (x) β ) γ + ϱ,(3)
div.p: where µ 1 , µ 2 , α, β and γ are the positive real numbers with αγ ∈ (0, 1), βγ ∈ (1, ∞) and ϱ > 0. Then, the origin x = 0 of the system (2) is practically fixed-time stable. Furthermore, the following inequality
div.formula: { lim t→Ts x |V (x) ≤ min { µ -1 α 1 ( ϱ 1 -ω γ ) 1 αγ , µ -1 α 2 ( ϱ 1 -ω γ ) 1 βγ }} . (4
div.p: is used to represent the residual set of the system (2) with 0 < ϖ ≤ 1. The convergence time can be derived as
div.formula: T s ≤ 1 µ γ 1 ϖ γ (1 -αγ) + 1 µ γ 2 ϖ γ (βγ -1) . (5
div.p: Remark 1 Inspired by the literature [33], for the convenience of derivation, in the process of the proof in this paper, all the parameters in the inequality (3) are selected as follows: γ = 1, α = 3 4 , β = 2. Lemma 2 [34] For x ∈ ℜ and any constant ε > 0, we have
Lemma 3 [32] Consider

div.p: Lemma 5 [35] f (Z) : ℜ m → ℜ, which is a continuous function on a compact Θ X , can be approximated by a fuzzy logic system W T S (Z) for any constant τ > 0, that is
div.formula: sup X∈ΘX f (Z) -W * T S (Z) ≤ τ. (9
div.p: where
div.formula: Z ∈ Ω z ⊂ ℜ q , W * = [w 1 , • • • , w l ]
div.p: T ∈ ℜ l denotes the optimal weight vector, and l is the number of the fuzzy rules.
T is the membership function vector with s i (Z) being chosen as the commonly used Gaussian function of the form
div.formula: s i (Z) = exp [ (Z -υ i ) T (Z -υ i ) η 2 i ] , i = 1, • • • , l. (10
div.p: where
div.formula: υ i = [υ i1 (Z) , • • • , υ iq (Z)]
div.p: T represents the center of the receptive field and η i is the width of the Gaussian function.
Remark 2 Lemma 5 shows that any unknown continuous functions f (Z) can be approximated by a fuzzy logic systems to arbitrary any accuracy τ as
with ξ (Z) being the approximation deviation. The above Lemma 5 has been widely recognized and applied in many literature [36]- [38].
Lemma 6 [35] For ϕ ∈ ℜ, φ ∈ ℜ and any real numbers p > 0, q > 0, m > 0, we get
div.formula: |ϕ| p |φ| q ≤ p p + q m |ϕ| p+q + q p + q m -p q |φ| p+q .
div.p: Next, for convenience of writing, the time variable t will be omitted.
Assumption 1. There exists constant ψ i > 0 satisfying
div.formula: ψ i ≤ |ψ i (•)| , (1 ≤ i ≤ n) . Without loss of generality, ψ i (•)
div.p: is supposed to be strictly positive.

Remark 3 Compared with the existing assumptions, Assumption 1 has a broader description, but its conservatism is that ψ i > 0 is considered, rather than ψ i ≥ 0. Practically, many actual systems can fall into the class given in (1), such as single force mechanical arm [39], and so on. Base on the the mathematical model of these applications, Assumption 1 is able to be satisfied.

div.p: where µ 2 = μ2 2n . So far, the adaptive fixed-time tracking control design has been accomplished based on the backsteping algorithm.

The block diagram of the design procedure for the proposed controller is shown in Fig. 1. The proposed adaptive fixedtime control strategy is designed based on state feedback, which receives the state information through MCU (micro controller unit), and sends out the control signal through MCU, thus achieves the purpose of design.

IV. SIMULATION RESULTS
We show the adaptive practical fixed-time control method on a numerical example [35] 

where f 1 = 0.1x 2 1 , f 2 = 0.1x 1 x 2 -0.2x 1 , ψ 1 = 1, ψ 2 = 1 + x 2 1 , x 1 (0) = 0.3, x 2 (0) = -0.3. Our target is that the output signal can track the desired signal y d = 0.5 sin(t), and the tracking error can converge to a small neighborhood of zero at fixed time, meanwhile, all the signals of the closedloop system are bounded.
In this paper, the FLSs are utilized. 7 fuzzy sets are given with the fuzzy membership functions chosen as

In order to emphasize the contribution of this paper, the proposed approach in the paper and the adaptive finite-time control method, which was presented in [30], [31], are utilized to control the system (63), respectively. The simulation results are shown in Figs. 23456789. As can be seen from the diagrams, the better transient indexes, such as response time and convergence, and the better tracking performance have taken place in our proposed method.

It should be pointed out that the choice of design parameters has great influence on the performance of the closed-loop system. For example, the bigger the parameters K 11 , K 12 , K 21 , K 22 , the better the tracking performance. However, the results come at the cost of the bigger control signal. Fig. 3 and Fig. 4 show the corresponding response curves of the tracking errors and the control signals, respectively. In the process of simulation, for the convenience of adjusting design parameters, we set

By the trial and error, we choose The trajectory of the output y by utilizing the proposed approach is exhibited in Fig. 5. It is clearly shown that the practical output signal tracks the desired output y d signal well in the fixed-time interval. Fig. 6 illustrates the tracking error trajectory. Obviously, it is found that the tracking error can converge to a small neighborhood of zero. The response curves of the states x 1 , x 2 and the control law u are illustrated in Fig. 7 and Fig. 8, respectively, which illustrate distinctly that all the signals are bounded stable. Fig. 9 shows the trajectories of θ1 and θ2 . Therefore, we are able to obtain that the system is practically fixed-time stable, and the tacking error can converge to a small region of zero in the fixed-time. V. CONCLUSION By utilizing backstepping algorithm, finite-time Lyapunov stable theory and fuzzy logic control, a new adaptive practical fixed-time tracking control is developed. Theoretical analysis illustrates that under the presented control strategy, the closedloop system is practically fixed-time stable. The proposed controller ensures that the tracking error converges to a small neighborhood of zero at the fixed time, and the convergence time is independent of states. At the same time, all the signals of the closed-loop system are bounded. Simulation results show that the proposed method can provide faster convergence ability and better transient performance. Note that the proposed method involves a series of design parameters, which is a great difficulty for the corresponding control design and implementation. Meanwhile, the problem of adaptive fixed-time tracking control is only discussed for a class of strict feedback nonlinear systems. When some practical systems have the general forms, 1063-6706 (c) 2019 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission. See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information. the design of adaptive fixed-time control of other types of nonlinear systems is still open. In addition, the problems of parametric uncertainty and perturbation are not considered in the current research. These problems are interesting and significant and will be addressed under the framework of the existing research results in our later work.
